attributes.text: Includes library functions to work with the client’s viewport (window).
Returns an orientation normalizer value that should be added to device orientation to normalize behaviour on different devices.
Orientation normalizing value
The window to query

Returns the current height of the viewport (excluding an eventually visible scrollbar).

clientHeight is the inner height of an element in pixels. It includes padding but not the vertical scrollbar (if present, if rendered), border or margin.

The property innerHeight is not useable as defined by the standard as it includes the scrollbars which is not the indented behavior of this method. We can decrement the size by the scrollbar size but there are easier possibilities to work around this.

Safari 2 and 3 beta (3.0.2) do not correctly implement clientHeight on documentElement/body, but innerHeight works there. Interesting is that webkit do not correctly implement innerHeight, too. It calculates the size excluding the scroll bars and this differs from the behavior of all other browsers – but this is exactly what we want to have in this case.

Opera less then 9.50 only works well using body.clientHeight.

Verified to correctly work with:

  • Mozilla Firefox 2.0.0.4
  • Opera 9.2.1
  • Safari 3.0 beta (3.0.2)
  • Internet Explorer 7.0
The Height of the viewable area of the page (excludes scrollbars).
The window to query

Returns the current orientation of the viewport in degree.

All possible values and their meaning:

  • -90: “Landscape”
  • 0: “Portrait”
  • 90: “Landscape”
  • 180: “Portrait”
The current orientation in degree
The window to query

Returns the scroll position of the viewport

All clients except MSHTML supports the non-standard property pageXOffset. As this is easier to evaluate we prefer this property over scrollLeft.

For MSHTML the access method differs between standard and quirks mode; as this can differ from document to document this test must be made on each query.

Verified to correctly work with:

  • Mozilla Firefox 2.0.0.4
  • Opera 9.2.1
  • Safari 3.0 beta (3.0.2)
  • Internet Explorer 7.0
Scroll position from left edge, always a positive integer
